title: Simplicity, propriety of Century Gothic + flexibility, familiarity of Helvetica Neue
content:
I am updating an identity for my branding, design firm and I have recommended a switch in our corporate typeface. I am looking for a few suggestions which fit our criteria:

- capture the openness and friendliness of our current face (Century Gothic)
- with a more credible font that sets well and is part of a larger system (similar to Helvetica Neue, which some designers would like to see used)
- this larger system should include different weights, a nice italic, an expanded character set and solid numerals (distinct or non-lining figures would be a nice plus)
- we are also probably setting our name as a word-mark or initialed in this face, so it must have enough personality (or brand) to sit on its own

Some designs that came to mind were: Verlag, Scala (both families), Dax, Neo Sans, Gotham, Whitney, or even Apex Sans and Galaxie Polaris.

I know I've seen excellent suggestions on these boards. What do you guys think?

Thanks in advance for any help,

Sam
author: Sam Serif

comments.content: [Klavika](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415124707/http:/www.processtypefoundry.com/typefaces/klavika/index.html) OR [Locator](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415124707/http:/www.processtypefoundry.com/typefaces/locator/index.html) and [Locator Display](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415124707/http:/www.processtypefoundry.com/typefaces/locatordisplay/index.html) OR [Bryant 2](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415124707/http:/www.processtypefoundry.com/typefaces/bryant2/index.html) OR [Priori](http://web.archive.org/) OR [Vista (OT)](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415124707/http:/www.emigre.com/EF.php?fid=200) OR [Absara Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415124707/http:/www.fontshop.com/?fuseaction=catalog.fontpackage&searchby=manufacturer&displayfontid=FF.11512.0.0)

Great picks Miss Tiffany.

I like Klavika (go Facebook!) and Locator (nice italics).

Bryant 2 is beautiful, but I'm not sure if we're ready to go 'all rounded' yet. The numbers really are wonderful, though.

Overall, are there any picks that are a little safer, more friendly?

To me, Verlag was just nice, with a little character. The x-height makes it a little conspicuous and I think that keeps it from being perfect for our goals. The personality and sophistication, though, are right on.

[Neutraface Text](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415124707/http:/www.houseind.com/index.php?page=showfont&id=18&subpage=viewfonts) doesn’t have a very big x-height but there are four weigths and a very nice italic. The are distinct numerals, too. ;^)

Verlag is a great typeface. I have had the opportunity to work with it and found it works very well at small sizes. However, because it is a geometric it will have moments of feeling stiff. The italic, for instance, isn't a soft as you might find in something else. But, on the other hand, your color palette, visuals, and other tactile elements will go a long way into imparting friendliness across the brand.

Those are great adnix. They both give Verlag a run for its money (in features and consistency) without the fussy x-height. They're both familiar and proprietary. That is no easy task.

I love their numerals and special characters. We're considering a face called [Evo BQ](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415124707/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/berthold/evo-bq/), which has an ampersand that almost takes the font out of contention. Look it up and see what I'm talking about!

[Mark Simonson](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415124707/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Mark%20Simonson)'s [Proxima Nova](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415124707/http:/ms-studio.com/FontSales/proximanova.html) might be a little too geometric for your tastes, but it's surprisingly friendly, and has a good number of weights.

- Lex

Nova is nice. It is friendly and a pretty safe choice.

I saw [Neutraface](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415124707/http:/www.houseind.com/index.php?page=showfont&id=18&subpage=viewfonts) in a store [yesterday](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415124707/http:/typophile.com/node/30129) and liked it very much.
